text: today on the caucus on a day of stock
market jitters over the US government's
debt John Harwood and Jackie comms
discussed the ongoing negotiations in
Washington and the possibilities for a
deal to bring down the federal deficit
so Jackie there was sort of a confusing
picture on the debt and deficits last
week you had President Obama come out
and give this really tough speech going
after paul ryan and his budget plan on
the other hand he initiated some
negotiations that are designed to wrap
up by june in hopes of smoothing the
path for a debt limit increase what's
the difference between the things
they're going to kick down the road and
the ones they think they can settle
right now the best that can happen i
think the ideal is that they come up
with a general framework by the end of
june when they have to raise the debt
limit but if President Obama and the
Gang of Six that's in the Senate
negotiating if they had their way it
would be sort of a three-legged stool
revenues the entitlement programs like
Medicare and the sort of annual spending
for both military and and domestic
programs now you wrote over the weekend
about this gang of six that's trying to
negotiate a bipartisan deal in the
Senate what makes these six unique and
what are the prospects that six can
become 60 if they cut a deal with since
you need 60 to move anything in the
Senate well what's interesting about
these six is that you have three of the
most conservative Republicans in the
Senate and you have Democrats that
include one of the most liberal
democrats in the house who happens to be
the number two Senate Democratic leader
dick Durbin of Illinois the thinking as
if these six can come together you know
ultimately perhaps a critical mass can
come together now should the fact that
those six members are working together
whether or not their efforts cross the
finish line before 2012 or not that
would appear to be a confidence-building
measure for both parties as they try to
work out the debt limit the flip side of
what you just said is also true if the
Gang of Six agrees to something it could
build confidence if they fall apart they
say they'll come up with something soon
but if they fall apart that
be the opposite that would that would
really shake confidence because this is
like the last best hope for
bipartisanship we saw on the potential
government shutdown a couple of weeks
ago we went right up to the last hour
how confident should American should the
financial markets be that in fact they
can avoid that situation I would say
confident it's never been breached
before ultimately something happens but
we have a new Congress here and there
are a lot of people in the House
Republican caucus that if you you know
that are saying they don't believe it
they just simply do not think that it
would be a big problem Pat Toomey says
Tim Geithner's hyping the potential
exactly reaction so that makes the job
of like you say Speaker Boehner and
Mitch McConnell particularly hard it's
not just politics that's dividing the
two they really believe different things
oh absolutely i mean this weird time in
our history where the differences
between the parties have never been more
clear
